The Korean alphabet, known as Hangul or Hangeul (한글) in South Korea, has been in use, to a greater or lesser extent, since its creation in the 15th century. Currently, both South and North Korea favor its use over Hanja (한자 / 漢字) or Chinese characters.


		It is composed of 10 vowels and 14 consonants that can be combined to form syllables. These syllables must begin with a consonant, after which we must place a vowel. Syllables can end either with a vowel or with a consonant.


		Vowels. We can distinguish two main types: vertical ones (ㅏ or ㅓ) and horizontal ones (ㅗ or ㅜ). The difference between them lies in where the initial consonant of the syllable will be placed; for the vertical ones, it will be on its left, and for the horizontal ones, it will be above them. In addition, we have a set of special vowels that contain the sound y (ㅑ or ㅛ) and behave just like we have learned. Finally, we can form diphthongs, like ㅐ or ㅟ; you can observe that the former is just like before, and the latter has a little gap in its upper left corner for you to place a consonant. As every one of them behaves exactly like a vowel in a syllable, we have grouped them together for simplicity.


		Consonants. Consonants are the characters that begin and optionally end a syllable. A special case here is ㅇ, which acts as a null consonant when our syllable starts with a vowel, but has its own sound when we place it at the end of the syllable. This pattern of having different sounds depending on their location inside the syllable is not unique to ㅇ: ㄷ, ㅅ, ㅆ, ㅈ, ㅊ and ㅎ all change their transcription to t when placed at the end; ㄱ and ㄲ change to k; ㅂ changes to p.


		Syllables. These are the basic units used to form words. Syllables are compound character blocks that contain one or more consonants and exactly one vowel (including diphthongs and the vowels with y sounds). To build them, we follow a similar approach to that used when grouping a single vowel with a consonant: the first letters tend to be placed at the top and/or on the left, while the final letters are usually at the bottom, with any medial ones being just between them in the remaining gap.


		Examples.
 		-Vowels: ㅏ (a) and ᅩ (o), associated with the syllables 아 and 오.
 		-Syllables:
 			수 (su): ㅅ (s) + ㅜ (u)
 			쟁 (jaeng): ㅈ (j) + ㅐ (ae) + ㅇ (ng)
 			넣 (neot): ㄴ (n) + ㅓ (eo) + ㅎ (t at the end of a syllable)
 			한 (han): ㅎ (h) + ㅏ (a) + ㄴ (n)
 			글 (geul): ㄱ (g) + ㅡ (eu) + ㄹ (l).


		Note on pronunciation. The transcriptions provided here are just a way to write the characters using the Latin alphabet, and thus they do not stand for pronunciations. Inclusion of audio files to help in this matter is not currently planned, but we encourage learners to expose themselves to native material as soon as possible.
